qas.question: What is often found sweeping unbroken from floor to ceiling on the interior of Gothic buildings?
Where are the verticals found repeated in the interior of Gothic buildings?

answers.text: the treatment of the windows and wall surfaces

qas.question: What sort of feature is created by the use of vertical elements in gallery and window tracery?
What does the use of vertical elements help to counteract?

answers.text: horizontal divisions of the interior structure

qas.question: What is often found completely broken from floor to ceiling on the interior of Gothic buildings?
Where are the verticals never repeated in the interior of Gothic buildings?
What sort of feature is ruined by the use of vertical elements in gallery and window tracery?

plausible_answers.text: horizontal divisions of the interior structure

qas.question: What does the use of vertical elements harm the most?

context: On the interior of the building <a0_0><b4_0>attached shafts<b4_0/><a0_0/> often sweep unbroken from floor to ceiling and meet the ribs of the vault, like a tall tree spreading into branches. The verticals are generally repeated in <a1_0>the treatment of <b5_0>the windows and wall surfaces<b5_0/><a1_0/>. In many Gothic churches, particularly in France, and in the Perpendicular period of English Gothic architecture, the treatment of vertical elements in gallery and window tracery creates <a2_0><b6_0>a strongly unifying feature<b6_0/><a2_0/> that counteracts the <a3_0><b7_0>horizontal divisions of the interior structure<b7_0/><a3_0/>.
